subject: dbus-sensors: Support DPS310 and SI7020
commitMessage:
dbus-sensors: Support DPS310 and SI7020

Infineon DPS310 pressure and temperature sensors for the Blyth
and Storm King Panel, as well as the Silicon Laboratories
SI7020 type sensors.  This provide OpenBMC with the ability
to have the DPS310 pressure and temperature sensors on dbus via
dbus-sensors through IIO.  Also the Silicon Laboratories SI7020
type sensors provide OpenBMC with temperature sensor on dbus via
dbus-sensors throught IIO.

Tested: busctl introspect --no-pager xyz.openbmc_project.IIOSensor \
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/pressure/Station_Pressure returned
results consistent with location of the Rainier system.
busctl introspect --no-pager xyz.openbmc_project.IIOSensor \
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/Ambient_1_Temp
busctl introspect --no-pager xyz.openbmc_project.IIOSensor \
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/Ambient_2_Temp returned
results consistent with location of the Rainier system.

Tested: busctl introspect --no-pager xyz.openbmc_project.IIOSensor \
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/pressure/Station_Pressure returned
results consistent with location of the Everest system.
busctl introspect --no-pager xyz.openbmc_project.IIOSensor \
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/Ambient_1_Temp
busctl introspect --no-pager xyz.openbmc_project.IIOSensor \
/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/Ambient_2_Temp returned
results consistent with location of the Everest system.

Author: Eddie James <eajames@linux.ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Bruce Mitchell <bruce.mitchell@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I18e46f2317d2bafde643d900d0d339e16ae4ae60

Patch Set 54:

> Patch Set 47:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> Andrew J.,
> 
> Same basic answer to all your questions:
> Just took the code that I was given and did my best to get done
> by the end of June 2021.

Yep, we all have deadlines;  I will do my best to stay out of the way of you making progress, but at the end of the day, they're IBM deadlines, not OpenBMC deadlines.  The code will be merged to OpenBMC when we're confident that it's reliable, high quality, and maintainable.

> 
> -- 
> Bruce

It would help a lot if you could address comments in blocks, or explicitly state when you're not by ACKing if you intend on fixing it but haven't yet.  This helps maintainers to stay sane and not have to re-review the same issues repeatedly.

As far as "just took the code I was given" with respect, you're taking charge of this code, regardless of who wrote it originally.  The owner needs to understand it, and the tradeoffs it makes and how it's used.

2 sentences is rarely a large enough commit message for a completely new feature.

Some immediate questions I have:
Why were the existing hwmon sensors classes not useful?
What features does this support?
Is there an associated EM config change?

Hi Ed,

Thank you for reviewing and feedback.

The main feature this provides it Altitude of the system,
this is (will be) computed from the pressure via standard
formulas.  This is needed for knowing air density for
cooling and fan control.  Also used by other subsystems
to tell if the costumer is using the system above the 
specified altitude limit.

These are the requirements I was given:
    How to handle Altitude in userspace https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/649
    Rainier - Add DPS310 ambient & altitude sensor configurations https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/2652

The associated EM config change 43416: entity-manager:
    Adds support for DPS310 altitude | https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/43416

In your commit message please, once it's there we can iterate.

Just FYI, you might want to avoid the term "requirements", and focus on value that this adds to openbmc.

I understand.

is I have a line Author: Eddie James <eajames@linux.ibm.com>
as I am not the original creator.

This seems like a very poor way to identify a pressure sensor versus a temp sensor.  I'm not sure why you're trying to differentiate (there's only one physical sensor).  Looking at this a little more, I'm not sure how this would work.  Can you elaborate a little on what you were thinking here?
There is one physical device with two physical sensors.  The Infineon DPS310 has both pressure and temperature sensors.

Indeed, as does the si7021. I wouldn't know how else to differentiate. The intent of a lot of this code was to provide a generic way to grab IIO sensors and report the individual measurements. It may or may not be the right approach - we could instead collate all the measurements from an IIO sensor and report that as a "Sensor"

This is getting the configuration path, right?  I wouldn't expect that to contain the word "pressure" also, if I did something crazy, and named a temp type sensor "under pressure" this check would fail.  I need to come back to this, and look at the calling code in main() to see how this is invoked to give a better suggestion for how to fix it.

The concern is generally that "thing" and "a thing" would both match this check.  Using sdbusplus::message::object_path along with filename() avoids this, because you can now do exact string matching on each component of the path.

Technically shawn is correct.  In practice this is undefined behavior that we just happen to rely on.  The short version is that std::flat_map is based on a vector.  for some vector implementations, end() points to the element past the last element.  When we call erase on the last item, we just happen to rely on this fact.

Technically this code should be resetting it, as should the rest of them.
Ack

This will break out of the loop and the iterator is not used. So from that perspective, not necessary to change.
But this does expect to only find one match at most, which probably is safe.

I missed this line and thought it continued looping looking for other things to erase.  Your new version is just fine; I just feel bad for my incorrect comment.
